Utterance: Hi! It’s great to see you again. How have you been?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been okay, a bit up and down with everything.
That’s understandable. How did journaling go for you?
It was helpful. I wrote down my feelings, and it felt good to get it out.
That’s wonderful to hear! What did you find most helpful about the process?
Just being able to see my thoughts on paper made them feel more manageable.
That’s a great insight. Sometimes, externalizing our thoughts can reduce their power over us. Have you noticed any recurring themes in your writing?
Mostly just worry about my mother-in-law and how it’s affecting my wife.
That makes sense. It’s a heavy burden to carry. How has your wife been coping through all of this?
She has her good days and bad days. I try to be there for her, but sometimes I feel helpless.
It’s tough when we want to support loved ones but feel powerless. Have you discussed how you can support each other?
We’ve talked a bit, but I think we could communicate more.
That’s a good observation. Keeping the lines of communication open is essential. How do you feel about scheduling regular check-ins with each other?
I think that could help.
Great! It could be a time for both of you to express your feelings and needs. How about your back injury? Have you taken any steps towards physical therapy?
I scheduled an appointment for next week.
That’s fantastic! How are you feeling about that?
A bit nervous, but also hopeful.
It’s natural to feel that way. Remember, it’s a step towards taking care of yourself. Have you thought about any specific goals you’d like to achieve with the therapy?
I’d like to regain some strength and be able to hike without pain.
Those are excellent goals! We can revisit them as you progress. How has your sleep been since practicing the breathing techniques?
It’s improved a bit. I’ve been able to fall asleep faster.
That’s great news! Consistency can lead to better sleep quality. Have you noticed any changes in your mood during the day?
I feel a little more balanced, but I still have moments of anxiety.
That’s understandable, especially with everything going on. Have you found any specific triggers for that anxiety?
Mostly when I think about the future and what might happen.
It’s normal to feel anxious about uncertainty. One technique that might help is grounding exercises. Would you like to try one?
Sure, I’d like that.
Okay, let’s do a quick exercise. Look around the room and name five things you can see.
I see the chair, a plant, a picture on the wall, a book, and the window.
Great! Now, can you name four things you can touch?
The chair, my phone, my shirt, and the table.
Excellent. Now, three things you can hear.
The sound of traffic outside, my breathing, and your voice.
Perfect! This exercise can help bring you back to the present moment. Would you like to incorporate this into your routine?
Yes, I think it could help during anxious moments.
That’s a great plan. Let’s check in on that next time. Is there anything else on your mind today?
Just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything.
That’s understandable. It’s a lot to handle. Remember to take things one step at a time. You’re doing well.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate your support.
You’re welcome! I’m here for you. Let’s continue to work together on these goals. Take care until next time!
Bye!
